reviewText: I am just so impressed that after all these years, the Eagles are able to put on such an amazing show.  You would think that at this point they might just mail it in, but they give an absolutely electric performance.  Don Henley is just amazing.  His voice is stellar, although his rendition of "Hotel California" seemed just slightly off.  Maybe if they had put it earlier in the concert instead of at the end, his voice would have been more fresh.  But he hits everything else just right. Glenn Frey is great too. Yeah, he's got a few corny jokes, such as dedicating "Lyin Eyes" to his ex wife, Plaintiff. (Get it?) His version of "Already Gone" is just amazing. Although he looks kind of silly dancing while Henley sings "All She Wants to Do is Dance."  I also gained new appreciation for Timothy B. Schmit.  People rag on him all the time that he's not a "real" Eagle and not as good as Randy Meisner, but I think he definitely holds his own.  "Love Will Keep Us Alive" is such a beautiful song.  And no Don Felder - who cares!  Steuart Smith proves to be a more than capable replacement. There are also some funny outtakes at the end of the second disc, especially one involving Don Henley and his guitar. If you like the Eagles, you will LOVE this DVD.

reviewText: This is a well-produced HUGE SPECTACULAR show put on by 50% of a great American band once known as The Eagles. Unfortunately their success drove the other 50% of the band away. Ever since its been a Don Henley/Glen Frey solo project with whomever to help out with the instruments. Don and Glen are great, don't get me wrong. Love them! But please don't call this outfit The Eagles. The real Eagles, the four guys who wrote and recorded virtually all of their trademark songs, were Henley and Frey and Randy Meisner and Bernie Leadon. The Eagles name was made by these four - in fact it was Bernie who came up with the name. After Bernie and Randy left the other two had every right to carry on performing the songs they wrote; they should have come up with a new band name. I just don't think it's right for other musicians to cash in on the work and the name of other people. (I will applaud Timothy B. Schmidt for paying tribute to Randy Meisner when the band was inducted into the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame. Randy was really moved by that gesture and it shows what a class act Timothy is.) Anyway, there have been lots of great old bands carrying on with new people under the old name, and I have never been okay with this. Great new musicians should have their own band name and let people judge them on their owm merits. Peace!

reviewText: I'm a Melbourner who attended this concert and it's fantastic to see how perfectly the experience was captured on this DVD collection. Finally a DVD release from a band with a peerless catalogue which doesn't skimp on material - on Farewell 1, they give you EVERYTHING - I can guarantee you, that was played at this concert.The sound is superb, the filming appears to have been done on HD which works fine; the look is filmy - not harsh like older video formats. This concert's material is perfectly chosen - I can't think of any track that I would have wished for - maybe 'Pretty Maids in a Row' but you can always run back to your copy of 'Hell Freezes Over' for that. Everyone is in great voice - it's nice to see Glen Frey taking his rightful place as band leader - he looks like he's having a ball - as if it's all new for him again. 'Take it to the Limit' is absolutely superb, even without Randy Meisner. You don't exactly miss Don Felder's presence although I think the extra 10% of having his wonderful touch on the guitars would've been the icing on the cake. They appear to be very unified without him though so maybe this is the only way it works for the band. Lots of terrific tracks from the solo careers - particularly Henly. Joe Walsh has a day out, playing crankin' solos and clowning around. 'Life's been good' has been needed sorely on DVD for years. 3 hours of vintage Eagles, beautifully played, very faithful to recorded versions, perfect harmonies - what more could you ask for? I was aware of some criticisms here of overuse of fiddle on the arrangements. I disagree. The arrangements are excellent and the fiddle is tastefully used and faithful to the feel of every song in which it features. Just purists who can't open their minds, even a little! If you like the Eagles, have no doubts about this one. Buy it.

reviewText: The Eagles Live in Melbourne 2004 is an outstanding disc.  The sound quality 5.1 surround and picture DVD quality are stupendous.  For those few Eagles fans on here, if you do not have that disc from this 2004 concert, released in 2005, you really ought to get it.Unlike Hell Freezes Over from five years earlier, the Eagles have hit stride, and they are more forgiving in letting each member shine individually:No More Cloudy Days (New Track), Hole In the World (new), You Belong to the City, Walk Away, Rocky Mountain Way, Sunset Grill, Life's Been Good, Dirty Laundry, are some of the tunes.  Joe Walsh really is a guitar God.  And it shows on this DVD.Also, it is after they kicked--for no good reason at all--original guitarist Don Felder out of the group. On this disc, a fellow that looks like a hatchet-faced greaseball in an oversize Texas roadsuit plays the lead guitar with gusto and vigor, note-for-note like Donnie Felder. And this is crucial as (trivia bomb) the Eagles feature two songs with the very uncommon guitar solo outtro (end of the song) with Life in The Fast Lane and Hotel California--check it out next time you listen to those cuts. The Eagles stil soar without Felder, and by tossing just a few sheckles into this studio journeyman's Fedora, the remaining Eagles split the cash cow in fewer pie pieces.  Ingenious.The Long Road to Eden, available only from the Walton family, is a sad countrified piece of grisle compared to this juicy concert from yesteryear. Got an Andy Jackson burning a hole in your pocket?  Go with Mebourne.
summary: Yep, 2004 was a vintage year for the Eagles.

reviewText: ...so what's with the four stars?Well, I happen to think that the Eagles were one of the three best American rock bands of the 70s. One of the best of all time, in fact. And this concert proves once again how timeless most of their music was and how well it has stood the test of time. (Their new album is pathetic and a blemish on their record, but the old stuff is great...)Anyway. There are plenty of highlights on this lenghty two-disc concert recording. Tremendous renditions of songs like "Heartache Tonight", "New Kid In Town", "Desperado" and "One Of These Nights". And Don Felder's replacement, lead guitarist Steuart Smith, is magnificent.But I don't love the arrangements. The blaring, monotonous horn section threatens to drown out everything else...most of these songs obviously weren't written with a horn section in mind, and the grotesque trumpet solos on the otherwise lovely "Tequila Sunrise" are an abomination.There are too many slick synthesizers and 80s-style keyboards here, and it makes some of the songs sound badly dated...especially the ones from Don Henley's solo albums. And what's with that utterly bizarre violin droning away on "Already Gone"?!Sounds pretty bad, doesn't it?Well, it really isn't. The horns only marr the outro to "Hotel California", not the song itself, and they are completely absent on several songs, as is the violin. Don Henley is fantastic on the slowies "Desperado" and "Wasted Time", and Glenn Frey does a terrific "Lyin' Eyes". And Joe Walsh's new song, the highly personal "One Day At A Time" is a must-hear, one of the best songs of the entire set.Walsh, the only showman of the lot, also clowns around in his most charming fashion on an enjoyable "Life's Been Good So Far", and his vocals are stronger than ever...he hits the high notes with impressive ease, sounding better than he did on 1994's "Hell Freezes Over".The Eagles can't quite make Walsh's "Walk Away" or "Funk #49" sound convincing, but they do a great "Boys Of Summer" (the mid-80s Don Henley-single), and a lovely rendition of their newest single, the gospel-like "Hole In The World". And I can't get over how great guitarist Steuart Smith is...his guitar sounds much better and more smooth than Joe Walsh's sometimes metallic-sounding Stratocaster, and he plays every fill and every solo to perfection.So, a lot of good here and some minor annoyances as well. The horn section should have been left at home, and solo violins don't belong in hard rock. But fans will most certainly want a look anyway, and most of this DVD is a very fine testament to the longevity of the Eagles and the immense quality of their music.

reviewText: I waited a long time to purchase this DVD.  It wasn't because of the set list because the band chose basically all the classic Eagles songs plus some solo hits from Walsh, Henley, and one from Frey along with three new songs.  It wasn't because I wasn't an Eagles fan because they are one of my favorite bands.  It was because Don Felder was absent.  But then I started to read reviews of the DVD which were mostly very positive and I rationalized that I did own the Who DVD (post Moon) Royal Albert Hall and I still think it's outstanding so I figured why not give the Eagles Farewell 1 tour a shot.  I'm very glad that I did because it has become one of my favorite concert DVDs.  The sound on this DVD is amazing and the camera work is fantastic.  Also, like the other reviewers said, the Eagles perform their songs as they should be heard and they perform almost all their classic songs and then some.  Okay, Felder is absent from the concert, but Henley, Frey, Walsh, and Schmitt help you forget about him plus Stuart Smith plays Felder's parts just as Felder would have played them.  Plus, Felder never sang lead vocals that much with the Eagles and the Eagles are a band that concentrates on vocals as much as instruments.  Speaking of the band, they all sound great.  Henley has gained some weight but his singing is still top notch, his drumming and percussion skills are both excellent, and he even plays some acoustic and electric guitar.  He is an underated musician but his drumming was always a vital part of the Eagles sound just like his singing.  Frey thankfully sings a lot more here than he did on Hell Freezes Over (only 3 songs on that one).  Some reviewers said his voice was going a little but I totally disagree.  His voice (probably best voice in the band) still is outstanding and he does a fantastic job on guitar and keyboards.  Frey is also underated as a musician but his guitar and keyboard playing were also vital to the Eagles sound.  Frey is also the one who talks to the audience the most during the concert.  Walsh is definitely a true rock and roll star.  Both his guitar playing and singing during this concert are extraordinary.  He is definitely one of the best American guitar players ever.  Some Eagles fans did not think Walsh fit in with the band but I have to disagree.  Songs like "Hotel California," "The Long Run," "Life In The Fast Lane," and "Heartache Tonight" would not have sounded as good without Walsh.  Schmitt is a little bit overshadowed by the other three in terms of singing but he still does a fantastic job on his two signatures songs ("I Can't Tell You Why" and "Love Will Keep Us Alive") and on bass and high harmonies.  Oddly enough, Schmitt is the only one who plays his instrument on every song throughout the DVD (there is at least one song where the other 3 only sing without playing anything).  The extra musicians do not hurt the performance at all and the horn section works here unlike with some other bands such as on The Who's Encore Disc of Tommy and Quadrophenia live.  The spotlight is still on Henley, Frey, Walsh, and Schmitt.  Highlights of this concert include "Heartache Tonight," "Hotel California," "Life In The Fast Lane," "Already Gone," "Peaceful Easy Feeling," "Lyin' Eyes," "Dirty Laundry," "Take It Easy," "In The City," "Walk Away," "You Belong To The City," "Funk 49," "The Boys Of Summer," "New Kid In Town," "One Of These Nights," "I Can't Tell You Why," "Tequila Sunrise," "Wasted Time," "The Long Run," "Rocky Mountain Way," "One Day At A Time," "Life's Been Good," and "Hole In The World."  The only performance that doesn't do it for me is "Desperado."  Don't get me wrong because I really like that song, but none of the Eagles really PLAY on it this time.  Frey doesn't play piano like he should and Henley should be behind the drums.  The performance for Hell Freezes Over is better.  That's the only let down, but Henley still sings the song very well.  For those who appreciate good humor, watch Frey and Walsh during "All She Wants To Do Is Dance."  Anyway, if you are an Eagles fan and appreciate good music I would definitely recommend this DVD.  It's one of the best filmed concerts ever produced.
summary: One of the best concert DVDs; definitely the best Eagles DVD

reviewText: You'd never know from my music collection that I like The Eagles, singularly or as a whole;nary a cd to be seen, except for one old Joe Walsh entry. This DVD caught my eye as it was used to advertise a big-screen TV at my local video rental place, and on a whim I rented it. It brightened up my weekend considerably.It's comforting to see so many of the veteran performers still operating at such an energetic level, especially after self-proclaimed headlong charges toward oblivion. This is addressed eloquently by Joe Walsh ("I was drunk once - for twenty years")in a new song called "One Day At A Time" - an exhilerating and typically Joe Walsh song that caught my attention from the very first note. Joe has always been my favourite Eagle anyway; he seems to have the best approach to life, and certainly he would have to be in the running for Funniest Rock Musician. He'd definitely have my vote.This two-disc set covers The Eagles from the start, and incorporates all the individual high points. As already stated, the energy level is way up there; it was recorded in Melbourne, Australia, with an audience ranging from little kids to oldsters like me, and not only is it a packed house, everybody is singing and dancing. No dozers here. And on stage, you'd never know these guys are cruising toward that nasty word "old" (Joe Walsh will be 59 in November; Don Henley is already there, and Glenn Frey will be 58, also in November); they never were a group to gyrate and race around on stage, but here they get together on some of the songs and hop in time to the music, clearly enjoying each other's music and style.All the great songs are here; "One Of These Nights","New Kid In Town" "Peaceful Easy Feeling";one of my personal favourites, "Heartache Tonight"; along with a spate of Henley's most singable, best-loved songs, "Dirty Laundry", "Boys Of Summer" "All She Wants To Do Is Dance", and Glenn Frey's hits as well, "Take It Easy", "Desperado". Joe Walsh's music is also well represented, but Joe really only has to be there for it to be worth watching; he makes a party wherever he goes. During "Life's Been Good" here, he dons a hardhat with camera attached and films the audience.This is a high-powered, well-produced concert; makes me wish I'd been there. As a DVD, it's a keeper.

reviewText: Disc one packs a punch with its twenty songs. You get a nice mix of Eagles hits; "The Long Run", "I can't Tell You Why", "Lyin' Eyes", "Tequila Sunrise", "Love Will Keep Us Alive", and Take It To the Limit, and a few solo hits; "The Boys of Summer", "You Belong to the City", and "Sunset Grill". If that's not enough for you, the Eagle's if shell out a few new tunes. Joe Walsh contributes a song he wrote about being sober called "One Day at a Time", and Glen Frey & Don Henley chime in with a song they wrote the night after September 11th called "Hole in the World". An interesting note about this song is that the group was sent to enter the studio on that day.Disc two is a ten song set that serves as a best of the best as the concert nears its conclusion. You're still getting the solo songs; "Life's Been Good", "Dirty Laundry", "Mountain Way", and "All She Wants to Do is Dance", and now you're getting the mega-hits; "Heartache Tonight", "Life in the Fast Lane", Hotel California", "Take It Easy" and "Desperado". The second disc also contains the only bonus feature which is an interview with the group. There's not much to it, but the Eagles talk about their sound, each other, and what's changed. Be sure to find out what the `circle of fear' is.Now that I've talked about the content, let's talk about the show. If I had to sum it up into one word, it would be sensational. Every member's performance is damn near perfect. I mean, even the solos are note for note. There's no denying their talent and musicianship with this performance. Frey sound wonderful vocally and nails down all of his piano and guitar parts with ease. Don Henley is the consummate frontman who also shows that time has not conquered his voice or drumming skills.Bassist Timothy Schmit's falsetto is still as pleasant and soothing, and Joe Walsh (still wacky) displays his knack for the fretboard without breaking a sweat. The group's five part harmonies are the heart and soul of the music, and despite different music styles and voices, manage to make it sound exceptional. The stage is rather large with a decent amount of back-up player in the shadows. The brass and string section really add texture to the music. The Eagles really know how to work the crowd by bringing the energy up for the up-tempo numbers, and bringing it back down for the ballads.The BadIt's sad that I know a few of the Eagles songs from television commercials that they've appeared in.The VerdictWhether you buy a ticket to their live performance (cha-ching) or buy this DVD, rest assured that you won't regret spending your hard-earned money. It's well worth it!

reviewText: To be honest, I wasn't looking to buy this.  I've never been a huge Eagles fan.  In fact, the reason I own Hell Freezes Over is because when I bought my DVD player it was one of the few high quality concert DVDs available.  It was impressive, both in sound and performance, and definitely gave me a new appreciation for the band.But, as I said, I still wasn't looking to buy this DVD.  I just happened upon it at Wal-Mart, and it was just too good of a buy to pass up (under 10 bucks), WITH a bonus CD!  So I bit.  I was a bit skeptical, because let's face it, those vocal parts are pretty high and those voices are now pushing 60 years of age. I've heard many ageing rockers that just can't get up there anymore.All in all, this is a wonderful concert.  It's 2 1/2 hours long, it's well recorded, both sound and picture wise, and the 5.1 surround is actually utilized much better than Hell Freezes Over was.Does this mean that this concert DVD is better than HFO?  In a word, no.  First, I think the excitement of the '94 reunion rubbed off on both the audience and the performers.  Secondly, I think the sound is warmer on HFO, as that was recorded under almost studio like conditions.  And even though Felder's replacement is a pro, and no doubt a more versatile and accomplished guitarist than Felder, I still miss his presence.  He was a full-fledged band member, and a sideman, no matter how talented, is still a sideman.  Also, even though the vocals on this DVD were still OK, I think that they've all lost a bit of their vocal power and range, with the possible exception of Joe Walsh.  They can still hit the notes, but not with the power and quality that they displayed on Hell Freezes Over.  Also, at least three of the backing musicians sing along with almost all the backing vocal parts.  On HFO, it was all Eagles and nothing BUT Eagles singing.But don't get me wrong here.  I am not criticizing this release.  It's top-notch, and I think it's admirable that they do as well as they do, considering their age and the fact that most singers of their vintage could not pull it off with the panache that they do.  It's just that they ARE showing their age, particularly with the vocals.  It's subtle, but when you listen to the songs that are common to both the HFO and Farewell Concert 1 back to back, it is noticable.So enjoy 'em while you can, I say.  These guys are consumate professionals, and I'm sure that when they can't cut it anymore, they will not comprimise their show or their name, even for boatloads of money.  This is a great concert by a great band.

reviewText: There are a lot of DVDs out there featuring concerts that have been edited, showing only parts of the performances and what not. When will they ever learn?Anyways, political comments aside, this is an excellent DVD of the band containing solid performances and a good selection of songs.  Certainly worth the purchase!

reviewText: There are just so many groups that still have what it takes after all those years. Unfortunately, there really aren't that many who are still standing and making great live performaces from the 70's. Yet, The Eagles have really triumphed those storms several years ago with the last concert, Hell Freezes Over, and they have finally done it again recently with their farewell tour. Arguably, it is a shame the group will no longer tour anymore for their songs, because those songs are one of the very few cornerstones of music today. That has been shown, in a well-put concert worthy of the music.Eagles: Farewell 1 Tour: Live From Melbourne, is a remakrable double disc DVD concert which makes up for what was left behind from Hell Freezes Over. The compilation includes some great live recordings of great classic like Hotel California, I Can't Tell You Why, New Kid In Town, the soulful Desperado, and other great songs. Also like Hell Freezes over, a few new never-before heard songs were also premiered on this compiled live set. reviewText: I thought Hell Freezes Over was one of the best concerts on DVD; this one tops it. The one band member that was missing (and sorely missed) was Don Felder.  He has been replaced by a session guitarist Steart Smith.  Even though Smith plays the guitar solos very precisely and close to the versions on disc, I missed the nice guitar interplay and chemistry between Felder and Walsh that was in "Hell Freezes Over."  There is a lot less chemistry between Stewart and Walsh.The highlight of this concert disc is Joe Walsh.  He is such an incredible guitarist and his guitar solos are impeccable.  On the solo on Hotel California at the end, he totally blows away the session guitarist.  Joe Walsh's solo songs and hits from James Gang days are a very welcome addition to this concert.What is also great in this disc are the inclusion of hits such as "The Long Run," "Heartache Tonight," "New Kid in Town," "One of These Nights," and "In the City."  Hotel California is played very close to the album version, unlike the unplugged version on "Hell Freezes Over."The DTS sound quality and the concert footage are just wonderful.  If you are an Eagles fan, this is a must-have, and it goes well on the shelf alongside "Hell Freezes Over."  Highly recommended!!

reviewText: Back in the `70s, the Eagles latched onto something that seemed very creative at the time. The `country rock' sound that was developed by Gram Parsons and the Byrds in the late `60s got polished to a high-pitched sheen by Glenn Frey, Don Henley, Randy Meisner and Bernie Leadon, eventually abetted by Don Felder on lead guitar. Their first four albums were all crucial to their era, and brought `country-rock' to the forefront of popularity. By the time that they released "Hotel California," they were recognized as huge stars, and their creativity reached significantly beyond the standard arrangements of country rock. Then, `punk rock' attempted to change all that. The Eagles dismissed the do-it-yourself aesthetic of punk as a laughable aberration. Instead, they entered the recording studio for what seemed like years, only to emerge in 1979 with the most boring and ill-conceived album of their career, a poorly focused effort that was appropriately entitled "The Long Run." Judging by sales figures, the Eagles were right, though. Bands like the Buzzcocks and Stiff Little Fingers languished and then fell apart, while "The Long Run" went platinum. Still, though, the band recognized that their relevance was diminishing, and they disbanded soon afterward. They haven't released a studio album since then.Twenty-five years later, the band is touring and drawing crowds as if they had never left. In the interim, a collection of their greatest hits has become the best-selling album of all time, so in reality, they never really did go away. Without any considerable addition to their catalog of tunes, the band has toured sporadically, demanding outrageous ticket prices, and yet continually selling out stadiums around the world. This time around, the tour was mockingly entitled the "Farewell 1 Tour", and this DVD captures one complete show as performed in Melbourne, Australia. As this audience ascertains, fans of the band now consist of a mixed group of three generations, all of whom seem to think that the year is 1977, and "Hotel California" is still at the top of the charts. (As a side note, it is rather obvious that for this show at least, the band sent out roadies to ensure that the front row was filled entirely with attractive women, a rather transparent and ridiculous maneuver at this point of the band's career.)The strange thing, though, is that three of the five `original' bandmembers are no longer aboard, and their contributions are unacknowledged here, except for a performance of Meisner's "Take It to the Limit". Joe Walsh has been an Eagle for the last two albums only, and Timothy B. Shmit didn't join until the sessions for their last album, yet they now consist of 50% of the `official' band, along with leaders Glenn Frey and Don Henley. As a longtime fan, I will always consider Schmit as a member of Poco (with whom he released over ten records and wrote nearly one hundred songs) and Joe Walsh as a solo artist. From a historic perspective (but certainly not a financial one), their careers as "Eagles' seems secondary to me, but it is their presence that fleshes out what otherwise would have been reduced to a singing/songwriting duo.Interestingly, this collection relies heavily on the subsequent solo work of Frey and Henley ("The Boys of Summer", You Belong to the City" "Dirty Laundry"), and the previous solo work of Walsh ("Rocky Mountain Way", "Funk #49"). Classic tracks like "Peaceful Easy Feeling," "Life in the Fast Lane," "Lyin' Eyes," "New Kid in Town," "Hotel California" and "Already Gone" are the reason that people show up, though, and here, they sound like spit-and-polish versions of the original studio recordings. There is no doubt that this band has the goods to play these tunes to perfection. For me, though, the net result is that I really miss Meisner, Leadon and Felder. They were integral to the band when the band was at its most creative, and their absence is palpable. In this configuration, the performances are extremely tight and well-rehearsed, leaving virtually every note sounding processed to perfection. Apparently, this is exactly how their contemporary audience loves them, so I cannot deny the `new' Eagles their extended run of popularity. Still, though, I can't help but wonder how I could ever miss them if they won't ever go away.  B  Tom Ryan
summary: Still Retiring After All These Years...

reviewText: Just got finished watching this, and I came away once again very impressed with the pure muscianship and attention to production. These guys are known perfectionists and it shows. Some say their live performances sound too much like the records, but on this one they spice it up a little more than on Hell Freezes Over, though there aren't many cool acoustic ones like on that DVD. This one is less stiff than HFO too.  Don Felder is missing on this one (out of the band since '01), but the guy filling in does a OK job, though it's just not the same on Hotel California. I thought the best performance was Walsh's Funk #49. It demands to be rocked LOUD in DTS. As with HFO, the recording quality is superb with DTS as the only surround option (just as HFO & Henley's DVD). The Eagles do this as DTS is better than Dolby as it uses less compression, and they can increase the video resolution when the Dolby track is left off.  In fact, I think this DVD sets the standard in sound quality for live mixes.  I have the Hotel California DVD-Audio, and the mix and realism sounds better here due to more available tracks to mix from and it utilizes higher resolution digital recording (though nothing can touch the resolution on a DVD-Audio or SACD).  Overall, there's more songs, and it's more of a rockin' set than HFO. Frey & Schmit look great while Henley, and especially Walsh, are starting to show their age (was that Hermes pajama bottoms Walsh was wearing?). Though Walsh's voice sounds the freshest. If you like great music, buy this. If you have a great sound system, buy this, as it will really show it off and make you glad you spent the big bucks.  As a last note, the Eagles share my passion for wine.  When their manager, Irving Azoff, shared some Lafite Rothschild with them in 1974, they began putting in their tour contracts that first growth Bordeaux would be in their dressing rooms.  Some may say that this is a primadona request, but I can't think of a better perk.
